column4: can anyone paste a normal /etc/sudoers file?  i can't seem to get it to work without *not* needing a password....
man sudoers
there's a specific example pertaining to your question in there; and sudoers is NOT something you should mess with unless you understand what you're doing
the freakin' expert install doesn't enable it. :P
enable nopasswd? Of course not.
huh?
what's confusing about that? nopasswd in sudoers is a MASSIVE security risk which should only be taken by people who Know What They're Doing... not, ever, by a default OS setting.
resiak: i should say SANE os...
well, i didn't enable it....
i don't doubt that i didn't add my user correctly though.
oo, triple negative. What precisely do you want to do?
have my sudoers work for my user like it used to on a normal install.
what's that, then?
when i run 'gksudo foomother', it doesn't ask me for my password; it just runs.  i want it to ask me for my password.
oh. you want to be prompted for a password for ALL actions? what does your line in /etc/sudoers say?
root    ALL=(ALL) ALL
andrew  ALL=(ALL) ALL

that WILL prompt for a password the first time, and keep the password for 15 minutes, by default. After 15 minutes without sudo, it'll prompt again. If you want to change the timeout, that's possible too. Not sure whether gksudo has some extra stupid password-keeper in addition.
well, i'm never asked.
if you use plain sudo at a shell, do you get asked?
no.
then this version of sudo is broken and you should probably purge and reinstall it. But I don't believe you; I suggest you wait for it to timeout and then try again; I bet you get prompted.
ok, i'll try that.  thanks.
